QuoteText: Archangel, here's why obvious child keeps accusing you of arguing that your god is an epic liar. Your theory about God "throwing" stars into the universe, yet allowing the light from all these stars to be visible on earth within a single day, requires God to have increased the speed of light by trillions of times. Not only is this theory both scientifically impossible and biblically inconsistent, it also means that God intentionally took time to create an elaborate fabrication of cosmology on a scale that can be no less described as epic.
ResponseText: Or to have created the photons at the midpoint along their journey! Don't forget that possibility! Granted, there is no conceivable way to test either possibility anyway.... At least in the ancient Aristotelian/Ptolemaic cosmologies employed by most early and medieval Christian thinkers, the distances are not so vast as to raise the issue of God's honesty in the first place. That, for me, is why creationism is such a preposterous idea. Regardless of whether the untestable changing-speed-of-light idea or the equally untestable photons-created-in-mid-transit is how God did it, he's a deceiver either way. He gave us the power of reason, which serves us perfectly well for explaining any number of natural phenomena. But use it on some phenomena, and it gives us systematically false results -- even though God himself set things up that way, and (as Descartes noted) gave us no way to discern that falsehood. I've said it before, and I'll say it again: One might as well worship a trickster deity like Loki or Coyote.

QuoteText: There are, presumably, some escapes from these two questions if you are determined to be literal. One is the idea I put forward (and you dismissed) in the link above - the universe is as old as science claims it to be, but God made it 'at' 6000 years ago, complete with an entirely real history.
ResponseText: But an entirely real history that is completely indisitinguishable from an entirely fabricated history! Bertrand Russell laid this to rest a century ago. I can't disprove the idea that the entire world was created last Thursday, but I'd be utterly daft to believe it.

QuoteText: Quite - see the linked OP! It's solipsism all over again. However - seeing as we both agree that YEC is daft anyway , that my idea shares this quality shouldn't affect YECers' acceptance of it. The real aim of my proposal was designed to allow YECers to maintain their belief in 'creation circa 4000BC', but prevents them from claiming that the scientific evidence is wrong in showing an old universe. Science shows a true history of the universe - and, if you choose to believe it, God set it all going a few millennia ago.
ResponseText: Agreed! I may have been a bit unclear. I was trying to point out the daftness of believing that the world is only 7-10,000 years old. But your point is very well-taken: Remember that geologist from Rhode Island who got a PhD studying fossils of extinct marine reptiles? Is this essentially his outlook? Still, it seems a bit dicey for most of 'em. If they admit that the scientific evidence is right, then declaring that, despite appearances, the earth is only 7-10,000 years old looks even crazier than it does now.
